summary: Unity (3D) car controller app using WheelColliders, supporting acceleration, steering, braking, wheel mesh syncing, and basic drag handling.
architectural_notes: Use Unity WheelCollider-based vehicle physics with Rigidbody centerOfMass adjustment and wheel mesh sync via WheelCollider.GetWorldPose.
Handle input in Update() and apply physics in FixedUpdate().
known_issues: Deployment/build process encountered a technical snafu; user requested a rebuild/retry.

existing_features.title: Create a playable 3D car controller experience in the browser that mirrors the provided Unity CarController behavior: rear-wheel acceleration, front-wheel steering, braking with Space, wheel mesh sync, and basic drag/friction handling.
Implement a tunable car settings panel matching the Unity script’s exposed parameters (motorPower, brakePower, maxSteerAngle, dragOnGround) and allow live adjustment while driving.
Add an in-app control/help overlay that documents the controls and the relationship to the Unity inputs (Horizontal/Vertical + Space brake).
Persist the user’s latest car settings (motorPower, brakePower, maxSteerAngle, dragOnGround) so returning users see their last-used values.

Define and apply a coherent, distinctive visual theme for the app UI (typography, spacing, surfaces) and scene presentation (lighting/background) suitable for a minimalist driving demo; do not use a blue-purple palette.
Add generated static visual assets for the app (logo and a subtle scene backdrop texture) and render them from the frontend as static assets.
Re-run the full build and deployment process for the existing Unity-style 3D car controller app and ensure the deployment completes successfully without errors.
If the build/deployment fails again, identify and fix the underlying build or deployment configuration issue so subsequent builds and deployments succeed reliably.

new_feature_requests.summary: Build a Unity car controller app using WheelColliders (rear-wheel motor torque, front-wheel steering, braking on Space, wheel mesh sync, and Rigidbody drag).
